# Source: https://biomejs.dev/formatter/

# Formatter 

Biome is an opinionated formatter that [supports multiple languages](/internals/language-support). It follows a similar [philosophy to Prettier](https://prettier.io/docs/en/option-philosophy.html), only supporting a few options to avoid debates over styles, turning into debates over Biome options. It deliberately [resists the urge to add new options](https://github.com/prettier/prettier/issues/40) to prevent [bike-shed discussions](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_of_triviality) in teams so they can focus on what really matters instead.

## CLI

[[![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)][Section titled "CLI"]](#cli)

The following command checks the formatting of the files in the `src` directory. It emits text differences if it finds code that is not formatted.

-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) npm](#tab-panel-151)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) pnpm](#tab-panel-152)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) bun](#tab-panel-153)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) deno](#tab-panel-154)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) yarn](#tab-panel-155)

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1npx @biomejs/biome format ./src</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1pnpm exec biome format ./src</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1bunx --bun biome format ./src</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1deno run -A npm:@biomejs/biome format ./src</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1yarn exec biome format ./src</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

If you want to **apply** the new formatting, pass the `--write` option:

-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) npm](#tab-panel-156)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) pnpm](#tab-panel-157)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) bun](#tab-panel-158)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) deno](#tab-panel-159)
-   [![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,) yarn](#tab-panel-160)

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1npx @biomejs/biome format --write ./src</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1pnpm exec biome format --write ./src</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1bunx --bun biome format --write ./src</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1deno run -A npm:@biomejs/biome format --write ./src</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

<figure class="frame not-content">
<pre data-language="bash"><code>1yarn exec biome format --write ./src</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
</figure>

The command accepts a list of files and directories.

![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)Caution

If you pass a glob as a parameter, your shell will expand it. The result of the expansion depends on your shell. For example, some shells don't support the recursive glob `**` or the alternation `` in the following command:

<figure class="frame is-terminal not-content">
<pre data-language="shell"><code>1biome format ./src/**/*.test.</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
<figcaption><span class="title"></span><span class="sr-only">Terminal window</span></figcaption>
</figure>

Shell expansion has a performance cost and a limit on the number of files you can pass to the command.

For more information about all the available options, check the [CLI reference](/reference/cli#biome-format).

## Options

[[![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)][Section titled "Options"]](#options)

Biome provides some options to tune the behavior of its formatter. Differently from other tools, Biome separates language-agnostic options from language-specific options.

The formatter options can be set on the [CLI](/reference/cli/#biome-format) or via a [Biome configuration file](/guides/configure-biome). As of v1.9, Biome supports loading `.editorconfig` files.

It's recommended to use a [Biome configuration file](/guides/configure-biome) to ensure that both the Biome CLI and the Biome LSP apply the same options. The following defaults are applied:

<figure class="frame has-title not-content">
<pre data-language="json"><code>1,12  &quot;javascript&quot;: 22  },23  &quot;json&quot;: 27  }28}</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
<figcaption><span class="title">biome.json</span></figcaption>
</figure>

The main language-agnostic options supported by the Biome formatter are:

-   indent style (default: `tab`): Use spaces or tabs for indentation;
-   indent width (default: `2`): The number of spaces per indentation level.
-   line width (default: `80`): The column width at which Biome wraps code;

See the [configuration reference](/reference/configuration#formatter) for more details.

## Ignore Code

[[![](data:image/svg+xml;base64,)][Section titled "Ignore Code"]](#ignore-code)

There are times when the formatted code isn't ideal.

For these cases, you can use a format suppression comment:

<figure class="frame has-title not-content">
<pre data-language="js"><code>1// biome-ignore format: &lt;explanation&gt;</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
<figcaption><span class="title">example.js</span></figcaption>
</figure>

Example:

<figure class="frame has-title not-content">
<pre data-language="js"><code>1const expr =2  // biome-ignore format: the array should not be formatted3  [4    (2 * n) / (r - l),5    0,6    (r + l) / (r - l),7    0,8    0,9    (2 * n) / (t - b),10    (t + b) / (t - b),11    0,12    0,13    0,14    -(f + n) / (f - n),15    -(2 * f * n) / (f - n),16    0,17    0,18    -1,19    0,20  ];</code></pre>
<div class="copy">
<div>

</div>
</div>
<figcaption><span class="title">example.js</span></figcaption>
</figure>

Biome doesn't provide ignore comments that ignore an entire file. However, you can [ignore a file using the Biome configuration file](/guides/configure-biome/#ignore-files).
